name: Forms.Field
comment:
`Field` represents a [`Form`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Form#Form) field


# Fields

@docs Field, Fields


# Creation

    myFormFields : Fields String
    myFormFields =
        fields
            [ ( "some-input", input )
            , ( "some-select", select )
            , ( "some-checkbox", checkbox )
            , ( "some-group",
              , group
                    [ ( "some-other-field", input)
                    , ...
                    ]
              )
            ]

@docs fields, input, select, checkbox, group


# Using a default value

    myFormFields : Fields String
    myFormFields =
        fields
            [ ( "some-input", inputWithDefault "Initial value" )
            , ( "some-select", selectWithDefault "Default choice" )
            , ( "some-checkbox", checkboxWithDefault True )
            ]

@docs inputWithDefault, selectWithDefault, checkboxWithDefault

aliases.name: Field
aliases.comment:
A `Field` can be :

  - an input field
  - a select field
  - a checkbox field
  - or a fieldgroup

It is looked-up using `comparable` so a `Field String` uses a `String` as
field key

aliases.name: Fields
aliases.comment: `Fields` regroups several `Field` and represents all your form fields.

values.name: checkbox
values.comment: Creates a checkbox `Field` with the [default bool `Value`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Value#defaultBool)
values.type: Forms.Field.Field comparable

values.name: checkboxWithDefault
values.comment: Creates a checkbox `Field` with a default value
values.type: Basics.Bool -> Forms.Field.Field comparable

values.name: fields
values.comment:
Creates a `Fields` using a `List`. This is the top-level function when
creating form fields
values.type: List.List ( comparable, Forms.Field.Field comparable ) -> Forms.Field.Fields comparable

values.name: group
values.comment: Creates a fieldgroup using a `List`
values.type: List.List ( comparable, Forms.Field.Field comparable ) -> Forms.Field.Field comparable

values.name: input
values.comment: Creates an input `Field` with the [default string `Value`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Value#defaultString)
values.type: Forms.Field.Field comparable

values.name: inputWithDefault
values.comment: Creates an input `Field` with a default value
values.type: String.String -> Forms.Field.Field comparable

values.name: select
values.comment: Creates a select `Field` with the [default string `Value`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Value#defaultString)
values.type: Forms.Field.Field comparable

values.name: selectWithDefault
values.comment: Creates a select `Field` with a default value
values.type: String.String -> Forms.Field.Field comparable

name: Forms.Form
comment:
`Form` is the top level type of the library. It is built with [`Fields`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Field#Fields)
and a [`Validate`](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Validation#Validate) function


# Forms

@docs Form, form, validate


# Field getters and setters

Sometimes you might need to get or set the current value of a `Field`. That is
what those functions are for

@docs getStringField, getBoolField, setStringField, setBoolField

aliases.name: Form
aliases.comment: A `Form` is made up of `Fields` and a `Validate` function

values.name: form
values.comment:
Creates a `Form`

    form someFormFields someFormValidate
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> Forms.Validation.Internal.Validate comparable err a -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a

values.name: getBoolField
values.comment: Gets the value of a bool `Field` (checkbox)
values.type: comparable -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a -> Maybe.Maybe Basics.Bool

values.name: getStringField
values.comment: Gets the value of a string `Field` (input/select)
values.type: comparable -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a -> Maybe.Maybe String.String

values.name: setBoolField
values.comment: Sets the value of a bool `Field`
values.type: comparable -> Basics.Bool -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a

values.name: setStringField
values.comment: Sets the value of a string `Field`
values.type: comparable -> String.String -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a -> Forms.Form.Form comparable err a

values.name: validate
values.comment:
Validates a `Form`. This runs the validation process and returns
a `FormResult`
values.type: Forms.Form.Form comparable err a -> Forms.Validation.Result.FormResult comparable err a

name: Forms.Update

aliases.name: Msg
aliases.comment:
These are the form `Msg`, they help updating a `Field`.

You need to implement them in your `Msg`, `update` function and use the helpers
in your view events.

`stringFieldMsg` is for string `Field` (input, select) and `boolFieldMsg` is
for bool `Field` (checkbox)

    type YourMsg
        = SomeForm (Forms.Update.Msg comparable)
        | ....

    yourUpdate : YourMsg -> Model -> Model
    yourUpdate msg model =
        case msg of
            SomeForm formMsg ->
                ...

    yourView : Model -> Html YourMsg
    yourView model =
        ...
            -- select/input field
            onEvent (Forms.Update.stringFieldMsg SomeForm fieldKey)
            -- checkbox field
            onEvent (Forms.Update.boolFieldMsg SomeForm fieldKey)
        ...

Note: you will want to name your message according to the form it is handling
in order to avoid confusion when using multiple forms

    type YourMsg
        = RegisterForm (Forms.Update.Msg comparable)
        | LoginForm (Forms.Update.Msg comparable)
        | ...

values.name: boolFieldCommands
values.comment:
Helps defining `Cmd` on bool `Field` events. You can use this function
to run commands when an event is triggered on a specific bool `Field`.

Note: this function only defines commands for the `boolFieldMsg`
values.type: model -> Forms.Update.Msg comparable -> (model -> comparable -> Basics.Bool -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )) -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )

values.name: boolFieldMsg
values.comment: Creates a form message that updates a bool `Field`
values.type: (Forms.Update.Msg comparable -> msg) -> comparable -> Basics.Bool -> msg

values.name: formCommands
values.comment:
Helps defining `Cmd` on both string and bool `Field` events.

    formCommands
        model
        formMsg
        yourStringFieldCommands
        yourBoolFieldCommands
values.type: model -> Forms.Update.Msg comparable -> (model -> comparable -> String.String -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )) -> (model -> comparable -> Basics.Bool -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )) -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )

values.name: stringFieldCommands
values.comment:
Helps defining `Cmd` on string `Field` events. You can use this function
to run commands when an event is triggered on a specific string `Field`.

    yourUpdate : YourMsg -> Model -> ( Model, Cmd YourMsg )
    yourUpdate msg model =
        case msg of
            SomeForm formMsg ->
                let
                    newModel =
                        { model
                            | yourForm = updateForm formMsg model.yourForm
                        }
                in
                stringFieldCommands newModel formMsg someFormCommands
            ...

    someFormCommands : Model -> String -> String -> ( Model, Cmd YourMsg )
    someFormCommands model key value =
        case key of
            "field-name" ->
                ( changeOrNotTheModel model
                , doSomeCommandsWithTheValue value
                )

            ...

            _ ->
                ( model
                , Cmd.none
                )

Note: this function only defines commands for the `stringFieldMsg`
values.type: model -> Forms.Update.Msg comparable -> (model -> comparable -> String.String -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )) -> ( model, Platform.Cmd.Cmd msg )

values.name: stringFieldMsg
values.comment: Creates a form message that updates a string `Field`
values.type: (Forms.Update.Msg comparable -> msg) -> comparable -> String.String -> msg

values.name: updateForm
values.comment:
This function will update a `Form` for you. Once you have implemented the
form `Msg`, use it to update the `Form`

    yourUpdate : YourMsg -> Model -> Model
    yourUpdate msg model =
        case msg of
            SomeForm formMsg ->
                { model
                    | yourForm = Forms.Update.updateForm formMsg model.yourForm
                }
            ...
values.type: Forms.Update.Msg comparable -> Forms.Form.Internal.Form comparable err a -> Forms.Form.Internal.Form comparable err a

name: Forms.Validation
comment:
This module provides the validation logic for the library. Please refer to
the [examples](https://github.com/ozmat/elm-forms/tree/master/examples) for a better understanding


# Field Validation

@docs FieldValidation, success, failure, configFailure


## Field Type

First of all you need to specify what type of `Field` you want to validate

@docs stringField, boolField


## Basic Validation

Then you create a validation function for this specific type, or use the
basic validation helpers defined below.

@docs validation, isChecked, int, float, notEmpty, length, email, passwordMatch


# Form Validation

@docs FormValidation, valid


# Validate

@docs Validate, required, hardcoded, optional, optionalWithMaybe, discardable, twoFields, fieldgroup


## Non-accumulative

The default behavior of `Validate` is to validate each `Field` and gather all
the errors while validating the all `Form` (it is accumulative).

But if you need a non-accumulative validation process (this means that the
validation stops at the first error encountered) there are non-accumulative
versions of the validate helpers.

They have the same name but finish with a 1. Do not mix them with the default
ones.

@docs required1, hardcoded1, optional1, optionalWithMaybe1, discardable1, twoFields1, fieldgroup1

aliases.name: FieldValidation
aliases.comment:
A `FieldValidation` represents the validation of a `Field`.

It can be a `success` or a `failure` (and sometimes a `configFailure`, please
refer to the [`ConfigError` definition](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest/Forms-Validation-Result#ConfigError)
and the [README troubleshooting section](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest)).

You are not going to use the `FieldValidation` itself but you will create a
`FieldValidation` function that will help you validate `Field`

aliases.name: FormValidation
aliases.comment:
A `FormValidation` represents the validation of a `Form`.

It is similar to `FieldValidation`: you are not going use the type itself but
instead you will create a `Validate` function (see below)

aliases.name: Validate
aliases.comment:
`Validate` represents the function that validates a `Form`.

It takes `Fields` and creates a `FormValidation`.

It usually starts with the `valid` function, representing the final result,
and then uses the different `Validate` helpers to validate each form `Field`

    validateForm : Validate String YourError Model
    validateForm fields =
        valid Model
            |> required fields "field-name1" (stringField ...)
            |> required fields "field-name2" (boolField ...)
            |> optional fields "field-name3" ...
            ...

values.name: boolField
values.comment:
Helps validating a bool `Field` (checkbox). By using this function you
basically say "this field is a checkbox, we are waiting for a bool here".
And then you pass your bool `FieldValidation` function that will validate
the bool

    type YourError
        = NotChecked

    isChecked : Value -> FieldValidation YourError Bool
    isChecked =
        checkboxField
            (\aBool ->
                if aBool then
                    success aBool

                else
                    failure NotChecked
            )

Note: if the field `Value` is not a bool, it fails with a `WrongType`
`ConfigError`
values.type: (Basics.Bool -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: configFailure
values.comment: Returns a failed `FieldValidation` using a `ConfigError`
values.type: Forms.Validation.Result.ConfigError -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: discardable
values.comment:
Validates a discardable `Field`. This is useful when you need to validate
the `Field` but don't need the result.

    ...
        |> discardable fields "terms" (boolField <| isChecked ...)
        ...
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: discardable1
values.comment: Validates a discardable `Field` (non-accumulative)
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: email
values.comment:
Helps validating a `String` that is an email. If the `String`is not an
email, fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = NotValidEmail
        | ...

    postValidation : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        email NotValidEmail postValidation
values.type: err -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: failure
values.comment: Returns a failed `FieldValidation` using an error
values.type: err -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: fieldgroup
values.comment:
Validates a fieldgroup. This is mainly useful when you need to nest another
validation process

     ...
        |> fieldgroup fields "job-profile" jobProfileValidate
        ...
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: fieldgroup1
values.comment: Validates a fieldgroup (non-accumulative)
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: float
values.comment:
Helps validating a `String` that can be cast into a `Float`. If the `String`
cannot be cast, fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = NotFloat
        | ...

    postValidation : Float -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        float NotFloat postValidation
values.type: err -> (Basics.Float -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: hardcoded
values.comment:
Hardcodes a value. This is useful when you need to harcode a specific value
during the validation process

    ...
        |> hardcoded "someHarcodedValue"
        ...
values.type: a -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: hardcoded1
values.comment: Hardcodes a value (non-accumulative)
values.type: a -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: int
values.comment:
Helps validating a `String` that can be cast into an `Int`. If the `String`
cannot be cast, fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = NotInt
        | ...

    postValidation : Int -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        int NotInt postValidation
values.type: err -> (Basics.Int -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: isChecked
values.comment:
Helps validating a `Bool` that is True (checkbox checked). If the `Bool`
is False, fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = NotChecked
        | ...

    postValidation : Bool -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : Bool -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        isChecked NotChecked postValidation
values.type: err -> (Basics.Bool -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Basics.Bool -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: length
values.comment:
Helps validating a `String` that has a specific length (> low && < high).
If the `String` has a different length, fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = WrongLength
        | ...

    postValidation : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        length 4 6 WrongLength postValidation
values.type: Basics.Int -> Basics.Int -> err -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: notEmpty
values.comment:
Helps validating a `String` that is not empty. If the `String` is empty,
fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = StringEmpty
        | ...

    postValidation : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        notEmpty StringEmpty postValidation
values.type: err -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: optional
values.comment:
Validates an optional `Field`. This will use the validation function if
the `Field` is not empty or use the default value otherwise

    ...
        |> optional fields "wallet" 0.0 (float ...)
        ...

Note: it only works on string `Field` so no need to use `stringField` here
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> a -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: optional1
values.comment: Validates an optional `Field` (non-accumulative)
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> a -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: optionalWithMaybe
values.comment:
Validates an optional `Field` with `Maybe`. Same logic than `optional` but
the default value is `Nothing` and the validated one is `Just`

    ...
        |> optionalWithMaybe fields "age" (int ...)
        ...

Note: it only works on string `Field` so no need to use `stringField` here
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (Maybe.Maybe a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: optionalWithMaybe1
values.comment: Validates an optional `Field` with `Maybe` (non-accumulative)
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (Maybe.Maybe a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: passwordMatch
values.comment:
Helps validating two string `Value` that match. If the strings
don't match, fails with the given error.

    type YourError
        = DifferentPassword
        | ...

    postValidation : String -> FieldValidation YourError a
    ...

    validateField : Value -> Value -> FieldValidation YourError a
    validateField =
        passwordMatch DifferentPassword postValidation

Note: if the two `Value` are not strings, it fails with a `WrongType`
`ConfigError`
values.type: err -> (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: required
values.comment:
Validates a required `Field`. This is the basic use case : the `Field` is
required and you want to validate it.

    ...
        |> required fields "first-name" (stringField <| someStringValidation)
        ...
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: required1
values.comment: Validates a required `Field` (non-accumulative)
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: stringField
values.comment:
Helps validating a string `Field` (input, select). By using this function
you basically say "this field is an input or a select, we are waiting for a
string here". And then you pass your string `FieldValidation` function that
will validate the string

    type YourError
        = EmptyString

    notEmpty : Value -> FieldValidation YourError String
    notEmpty =
        stringField
            (\aString ->
                if String.isEmpty aString then
                    failure EmptyString

                else
                    success aString
            )

Note: if the field `Value` is not a string, it fails with a `WrongType`
`ConfigError`
values.type: (String.String -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: success
values.comment: Returns a successful `FieldValidation` using a result
values.type: a -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

values.name: twoFields
values.comment:
Validates two `Field` together. This is useful when you need to validate
one `Field` that depends on another, but you only need to store one result.

    ...
        |> FV.twoFields fields "password" "password-repeat" (passwordMatch ...)
        ...

Note : the validation function takes two field `Value` so you cannot use the
`stringField` and `boolField` helpers here, you will have to deal with `Value`
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: twoFields1
values.comment: Validates two `Field` together (non-accumulative)
values.type: Forms.Field.Internal.Fields comparable -> comparable -> comparable -> (Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Value.Internal.Value -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err (a -> b) -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err b

values.name: valid
values.comment: Returns a successful `FormValidation` using a result
values.type: a -> Forms.Validation.FormValidation comparable err a

values.name: validation
values.comment:
Helps creating a basic validation function. It is useful when you have
a basic test and you only need to fail with one error.

    type YourError
        = MustBeEmpty

    emptyValidation : String -> FieldValidation YourError String
    emptyValidation =
        validation MustBeEmpty String.isEmpty
values.type: err -> (a -> Basics.Bool) -> a -> Forms.Validation.FieldValidation err a

name: Forms.Validation.Result

unions.name: ConfigError
unions.comment:
A `ConfigError` represents a configuration error on a `Field`. It usually
happens when there is an error in the `Fields` or the `Validate` function :

  - `MissingField` when the field cannot be found
  - `WrongType` when the field has a different type of `Value`

Note: if you have trouble debugging those errors have a look at the
[README troubleshooting section](http://package.elm-lang.org/packages/ozmat/elm-forms/latest)

unions.name: FormResult
unions.comment:
A `FormResult` represents the result of a form validation. There are
3 different states :

  - `Valid` reprensents a successful validation and holds the form result
  - `Invalid` reprensents a failed validation and holds the form errors
  - `Error` represents a misconfigured form and holds the configuration errors

name: Forms.Value

aliases.name: Value
aliases.comment:
A `Value` can be a `String` (input/select field) or
a `Bool` (checkbox field)

values.name: bool
values.comment:
Creates a bool `Value`

    bool True
values.type: Basics.Bool -> Forms.Value.Value

values.name: defaultBool
values.comment:
Is the default bool `Value`

    False
values.type: Forms.Value.Value

values.name: defaultString
values.comment:
Is the default string `Value`

    ""
values.type: Forms.Value.Value

values.name: getBool
values.comment: Returns the value of a bool `Value`
values.type: Forms.Value.Value -> Maybe.Maybe Basics.Bool

values.name: getString
values.comment: Returns the value of a string `Value`
values.type: Forms.Value.Value -> Maybe.Maybe String.String

values.name: string
values.comment:
Creates a string `Value`

    string "some input value"
values.type: String.String -> Forms.Value.Value
